title: How do co-authors actually write a book together? - Quora
tags: Breaking in as a New Author or Novelist

response.answer_text: However they choose. I’ve collaborated with at least six different co-authors, and all six worked differently. For one, we had a storyline we were following that we had agreed on at a cocktail party; the story was written as a series of letters, notices, news clippings, and so on. My collaborator wrote everything that was from the villain’s point of view (at least, I thought she was the villain), and I wrote everybody else — which wasn’t that much more, because her character had a habit of killing my characters. I’d write a piece and send it to her, she’d reply, I’d respond to that, and so on, until we finished the story we’d started with. For a short story I co-wrote with my wife, I was writing it and every time I’d get stuck I’d call to her, “What happens next?” and she’d tell me. She didn’t actually write anything. For one novel, my collaborator and I plotted it out sitting in my living room, with him providing most of the plot. I wrote the first draft, and he revised it. For another novel, we each had a list of things we wanted to include. We got together over lunch and worked up a rough outline, which I then wrote up in detail, and split into forty-two scenes (which did not match up to chapters). We then took turns choosing which scenes we wanted to write until we each had twenty-one of them. She wound up with the first two or three, so she wrote the opening, then sent it to me, I wrote my scene(s) and sent it back, and so on, until we got to the end. We would throw in little surprises along the way, things that weren’t in the outline, that the other then had to work with. It was an immense amount of fun. When we had a complete first draft we discussed some revisions (which were pretty extensive; some scenes had wound up out of order somehow), then I wrote the second draft, she wrote the third, and voila. For yet another novel, my collaborator had come up with the novel, written about two-thirds of it, then decided that he had no idea how to end it and it wasn’t working anyway, so I took over and rewrote the entire thing, which meant throwing out large chunks of what he’d written. The ending was entirely mine. And for a short story, I’d written a short-short and mentioned it to my collaborator; he asked to see it, I sent it, he suggested some revisions, I made them, he suggested more, and it went back and forth until we were both satisfied with it, whereupon I sold both our collaboration and the original short-short I’d written solo — they had wound up different enough to be sold as two separate stories. So — lots of methods.

Here’s an old article of mine. Conquering Collaboration - Moviegoers Want What Kids Love and Hollywood Often Ignores Them by Skip Press As a writer in Hollywood, I am constantly reminded of certain phrases: Writing is the loneliest profession. We’re looking for an original voice. Written by. Here’s the Hollywood translation: It’s hard to write something that sells. You only know it’s marketable when it’s bought. No matter how good your sold script is, you’ll be very lucky to get sole credit. Some other things I wonder about: Is that ink on those pages, or my blood? Do expensive classes and workshops really help, or does playing the lottery make more sense? If it’s so hard to find good scripts, why do they make so many crappy movies? That last one answers itself, and since obviously neither you nor I write bad scripts, let’s move on. Here’s a question I get a lot - How do they adjudicate the final credits on a show or movie, anyway? For the answer, go to the Writers Guild of America site at Writers Guild America West and look up their “Credits Survival Guide” for a full explanation of the credits process in the U.S. I get hundreds, even over 1,000 emails a week. Inevitably, each writer inquiry boils down to the same desire: the sharing of information for a more desirable result. Collaboration. It’s the lifeblood of Tinseltown. If you can’t collaborate well, stay away from Hollywood. Film, television and gaming are the most collaborative of all the arts and always changing. This makes for a neurotic business environment that can literally drive you crazy. Unfortunately, many aspiring screenwriters don’t realize the scope of collaboration and craziness necessary to get a film, show or game to market. They also often under-estimate the sophistication of today’s media audiences. Having a co–writer might be your first best choice on the road to being an experienced collaborator. When another person catches a plot hole in your script it helps you understand the ultimate end recipient – the audience. It’s easy to complain about the latest “piece of trash” you saw at the local cineplex and think you can do better. What you might not know is that most independent films that don’t get distributed do not start with a good screenplay. Hollywood executives know it. That’s why the credits of your favorite Hollywood blockbuster often have at least two credited writers and more uncredited; the executives hedge their bets by hiring the best writers available to cover all aspects of the story. On my Yahoo! discussion group, “Skip’s Hollywood Hangout,” professional writers, students, and filmmakers from all over the world collaborate daily. People offer notes on others’ scripts and loglines, share contact information, and participate in polls. Some members have tried working together, so maybe that’s why in the fall of 2003 I was asked for advice on co-writing. Since I was working out a screenplay with an English writer at the time, the collaborative process seemed an appropriate subject for a Scriptwriter column. Interestingly enough, the feature scripts I’ve sold were both co-written. In contrast, with one exception the scripts, treatments, short stories and novels of mine that have been optioned were my sole creation. A radio script and several TV scripts I wrote had other writers after I sold them. I had to fight for credit on the last two TV shows I wrote, the only time I’ve had to do so, but on a show where I was a staff writer the producer and I had almost no disagreements at all. In my experience, the good outweighs the bad. On another project, a best-selling “how-to” video, I received collaboration from my co-producer and others who did not want a writer credit. From working with co–writers new to Hollywood to being mistreated by a Hollywood jerk, I’ve seen it all in the collaborative process. So let me share that with you. Let’s start with the types of collaboration that can take place and problems that might arise. (a) Working with a co-writer who is more experienced than you. If you’re not a professional writer (someone who has been paid for your work) and you’re lucky enough to hook up with a pro screenwriter, do more listening than talking when the discussion is about the structure of the movie. If you’re discussing story only, that doesn’t change much, medium to medium. A good story can come from anywhere. It usually takes a professional approach to sell it, though. A pro will likely know tricks of the trade that you cannot intuit. For example, William Goldman wrote about writing a “blueprint” script to sell to a studio and then, once he had a deal, writing the script he really wanted. Unfortunately, he probably couldn’t get away with that today. Studio executives expect you to turn in the story that has been discussed. If you don’t, you’d better have something that’s a lot better (which may be how Goldman got away with it). (b) Working with a writer less experienced than yourself who writes in stone. By “in stone” I mean they think all the precious words they conjure are inviolate and must never be changed. If you are the recipient of such insistence, you must learn patience, even when explaining what may seem to you to be the most mundane facts. In the case of both of the features I sold, I had to deal with what I call “one baby syndrome.” When a parent has only one child, they take it much more seriously when the child has an injury or any other kind of hurt. In families with many children, bloody noses are relatively normal occurrences and not seen as life or death matters. It’s not always easy to convince inexperienced co-writers why it makes sense to cut a scene or a character. The first time I took on a writing partner, we worked out the story together and he drafted the script from our outline. I was busy putting up a play and didn’t have the writing time. The first draft was 30 pages too long and contained oddities like a page and a half soliloquy from a minor villain. It took me around an hour of enduring rolled eyes, yawns, face stretches, and chain-smoked cigarettes (his, not mine) to convince my co–writer that speech wouldn’t work and didn’t matter. I explained to him the old Harry Cohn (head of Columbia Studios in its heyday) “butt twitch” method. When Cohn was watching a screening and his butt twitched, he knew something in that part of the movie needed changing because he was bored and shifting in his seat. We finally achieved a balance on the screenplay, but only after several rewrites and a determination that he owned 60% and I owned 40%. As I recall, it took us a decade to sell that screenplay. I put the final polish on it alone, and my co-writer got it to a producer friend who sold it. (This after I arranged a previous option to a friend of mine.) (c) Writing with a writer less experienced than yourself who is too blinded by their own ego to see what works and what doesn’t. I was once paid to polish up a novel a rich attorney had been unable to sell but was convinced had great movie potential. (I didn’t see the movie potential but I took the job.) He then got it published, and wrote another novel on his own. He couldn’t get that one published either, so I offered some suggestions and introduced him to a publisher who published an electronic novel. The attorney has been unable to sell anything else, and doesn’t understand why – his ego won’t let him. As a ghostwriter, I wrote a book for a woman who saw visions and had delusions. She wouldn’t listen to me about certain market-based suggestions. I was paid for the book, but I left her to her own marketing. She couldn’t sell the flawed product she insisted on. In contrast, I was paid to write a book for a sensible fellow who would listen to all my suggestions and choose the ones that made sense to him. His book went to #1 in its category on Online Shopping for Electronics, Apparel, Computers, Books, DVDs & more. Some people have to learn to be flexible. When I was starting out, I sold a show to a kids’ TV series. The “show runners” rewrote my script instead of letting me do it, due to time constrictions of taping. I didn’t understand the process and was upset that my “precious words” were being changed. And that’s the only script I wrote for that show. I didn’t know then that whatever medium you work in, someone will always have suggestions. Even if you are an “A list Hollywood screenwriter” this is true. If you’re working with someone more experienced you must realize they may have a practical reason for certain opinions. Just make sure they are explained to you. If you’re working with someone less experienced, you will probably get to a point where you’ll have to deal with ego problems they may have. In that case, you must deal with it completely, or find another co-writer. (d) Writing with a writer, director or producer who is greedy if not downright evil. I once wrote a script with a fellow who convinced me that he could get the financing to make a low budget comedy. He was a fast-talking salesman and, I unfortunately only later learned, a con artist. After I put together a best-selling golf video, the producer who promised to finance it cut me out as a writer and refused to give me a credit. Only after I threatened a lawsuit did I get a paid settlement. He later lost his producing partner over such hijinks. A few years ago, a wealthy but neophyte producer paid a good bit of money to option one of my screenplays. Since she could finance the film, I introduced her to a director who had continually espoused great love for my script but never seemed to be able to put up any money to option it. Next thing I knew, my “baby” producer had been talked into letting the director rewrite the script. Luckily, the project fell apart, and I got the rights back. Concurrently, the same director hired me to write a couple TV show episodes (for non-union prices at a time when I needed the money) once he heard about the possibility of my movie getting financed. Again, only after threatening a lawsuit with the show’s distributor did I get a writing credit, and then less than what I deserved. I learned to avoid this type of situation by paying more attention to money and contracts. If someone offers you no money but promises you the moon, and/or if they won’t put a deal in writing, avoid them at all costs or pay a heavy price later. (e) The wonderful land of “notes.” Recently, I was in a meeting at Disney Studios courtesy of Gary Shusett and Sherwood Oaks Experimental College (see www.sherwoodoakscollege.com ). I speak at Gary’s events on occasion and other times I’m simply in the audience because Sherwood Oaks offers access to top Hollywood executives like no other organization in the world. At the meeting, the Director of the Buena Vista Motion Pictures Group explained how The Princess Bride went from a novel by an unknown writer to a G-rated box office bonanza. He also related how a co-writing team who didn’t like the “notes” they got from Disney cancelled their script option and failed to set up the project elsewhere as they thought they would easily do. (There’s that ego thing again.) “So what kind of writers do you like to work with?” asked one of the assembled aspiring writers. “Audrey Wells,” he replied. (Look her up on IMDb: Ratings, Reviews, and Where to Watch the Best Movies & TV Shows, you might be impressed.) Apparently, when given ideas to work with, Ms. Wells would regularly come back with great improvements on the executive notes. “Hey, I’m not a writer!” the executive exclaimed to the pleasantly surprised writers. “We can only come up with some ideas. When a writer can greatly improve them and make us excited, that’s what we want.” And that’s about what it all boils down to, isn’t it? The quality of the product is really all that matters. At the top level of a major Hollywood studio, an executive revealed that yes, they really do want quality at every step of the process. With The Princess Diaries, he had at first been reluctant to read yet another book (by a then unknown writer) about a girl who becomes a princess. Producer Debra Martin Chase convinced him. After reading the book – which is really about a girl who has an opportunity to become a princess but doesn’t want it – he drove to his boss’s house at 10:00 at night and insisted she read it. She stayed up late reading it, and they bought the book immediately. And that’s the kind of thing that happens when a great story comes along, whether it’s a sole creation or the product of a team. If I had to offer one rule in working with a co–writer or in collaborating on any project, it would be another old phrase – honesty is the best policy. If you’ve ever done a reading of a play or a screenplay that you’ve written, you’ve no doubt experienced surprise when laughs came at places you didn’t expect, and didn’t come when you anticipated them. You’ve found that speeches that looked so good on the page didn’t flow like hot honey out of your actors’ mouths. And so you learned to collaborate, which is only done effectively when everyone is honest about the process. These days, as I work out the story of a new screenplay with my English co-writer (a novelist of some note who has proven to me that she is also a competent screenwriter) I offer my thoughts without consideration because I know I am working with a professional. She does the same. We are both experienced enough with readers and viewers to know when something works and when it does not. Ego doesn’t matter, only the work itself. In getting to a sale, or to a completed production, successful writers remember the end recipient, that person in the dark who needs a lift, a thrill, or a laugh. It is never about the writer, only about the writing. The play is still the thing, and I hope you write great ones, alone or together. I hope I get to collaborate with you – from the audience. The End Skip Press is the author of the Complete Idiot’s Guide to Screenwriting
